population_specificity: 46 participants (22 young adults aged 18-35 and 24 older adults aged 65+) with musculoskeletal disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether balneotherapy, alone or combined with exercise, can improve sleep quality.
results_summary: Sixteen out of twenty-one studies reported improvements in self-perceived sleep quality, suggesting balneotherapy combined with spa treatments and physical exercise may be effective. However, the variety of treatments makes it difficult to isolate the effects of balneotherapy alone.
population_specificity: Healthy or sub-healthy subjects, and patients with fibromyalgia, ankylosing spondylitis, osteoarthritis, musculoskeletal pain, subacute supraspinatus tendinopathy, and mental disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of balneotherapy, water-based exercise, and land-based exercise on disease activity, symptoms, sleep quality, quality of life, and serum sclerostin levels in patients with ankylosing spondylitis.
results_summary: Balneotherapy showed statistically significant improvements in disease activity, symptoms, sleep latency, and quality of life in patients with ankylosing spondylitis, with benefits lasting at least 12 weeks. No significant changes in serum sclerostin levels were observed.
population_specificity: 60 patients (35 males, 25 females; mean age 40.9±11.2 years) diagnosed with ankylosing spondylitis.
effective_dosage: 20 sessions of treatment in groups of five to six patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of balneotherapy on spondyloarthritis by analyzing randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Two high-validity studies showed improvements in pain and quality of life, but overall evidence was insufficient to conclusively prove balneotherapy's efficacy for spondyloarthritis. Mixed results were observed across studies with varying internal validity.
population_specificity: Adults with spondyloarthritis, including subgroups with rheumatic disease, ankylosing spondylitis, and psoriatic arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence from human studies on the effects of hydrotherapy, spa therapy, and balneotherapy in treating psoriasis and atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: Most studies indicated that balneotherapy, spa therapy, and hydrotherapy may reduce disease effects by decreasing inflammation and improving living conditions, with improvements noted in the PASI score index for psoriasis. However, more clinical trials are needed to clarify the mechanisms of action.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis (AD) and psoriasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to gather information about the benefits and risks of water therapy (including balneotherapy) for cancer patients, focusing on its effectiveness and potential harm.
results_summary: The studies reported mixed results, with some showing significant improvements in quality of life, lymphedema, pain, fatigue, and BMI, while others found no changes. The overall evidence was heterogeneous and limited by methodological shortcomings.
population_specificity: Primarily breast cancer patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effectiveness of balneotherapy for improving the quality of life of patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy significantly improved the quality of life in RA patients, with positive effects observed from both mineral bathing and immersion in sand or mud. All included studies showed statistically significant improvements despite variations in treatment administration.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
effective_dosage: Sessions approximately 20 minutes long, using natural mineral waters enriched with elements or mud, at a water temperature between 35-38 °C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether balneotherapy (BT) alters gut microbiota composition in patients with atopic dermatitis (AD) and whether these changes correlate with clinical improvement (SCORAD reduction).
results_summary: The study found that BT altered the relative abundance of 23 gut microbial species, which correlated with SCORAD reduction. Microbial functions related to the gut-brain axis (e.g., GABA and tryptophan metabolism) were also affected, suggesting a potential link between gut microbiota and AD progression during BT.
population_specificity: 96 patients with moderate to severe AD (SCORAD-defined).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of balneotherapy on musculoskeletal disorder pain and perceived improvement among users of hot spring water in Southern Ethiopia.
results_summary: The study found that 83.2% of participants reported complete relief from musculoskeletal pain after hot spring baths, with significant therapeutic effects observed for joint pain, muscle pain, and rheumatoid arthritis after three or more days of treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with musculoskeletal disorders, including rheumatoid arthritis, visiting hot springs in Southern Ethiopia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (hot spring baths for three or more days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the importance of body core temperature (BCT) changes in balneotherapy and its potential for individualized treatment planning, avoiding adverse effects, and improving therapeutic outcomes.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the lack of standardized practices in balneotherapy and suggests that BCT could be a key parameter for understanding heat exposure effects, but it does not provide specific results on therapeutic outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate changes in public interest in balneotherapy during the COVID-19 pandemic in Italy and Japan using Google Trends data.
results_summary: The study found that interest in balneotherapy significantly decreased during peak COVID-19 periods in both countries but showed recovery afterward, with Japan exceeding pre-pandemic interest levels temporarily. Interest declined again later in 2020, correlating negatively with new COVID-19 cases and deaths.
population_specificity: Italian and Japanese general public.
study_duration: Data analyzed from 2016-2020, with specific focus on 2020 time spans.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of balneotherapy on reducing lower back pain and improving outcomes among adults using hot spring spas in southern Ethiopia.
results_summary: The study found that 77.8% of participants reported perceived improvement in back pain after balneotherapy, with significant associations linked to the type of hot spring used, male sex, and presence of neurological symptoms.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic lower back pain using hot spring spas in Sidama Region and Gedeo Zone, Southern Ethiopia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize existing evidence on the effects of balneotherapy on the immune system, particularly its anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory properties.
results_summary: In vitro studies and clinical trials showed that balneotherapy reduces pro-inflammatory molecules (e.g., TNF-α, IL-1β) and increases anti-inflammatory factors (e.g., IGF-1), especially in musculoskeletal diseases. H2S donors in thermal water were noted to counteract inflammation in psoriatic lesions and arthritic conditions.
population_specificity: Human and animal samples, with clinical trials focusing on musculoskeletal diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term efficacy of different thermal modalities, including balneotherapy, in treating osteoarthritis symptoms such as pain, stiffness, and quality of life.
results_summary: Balneotherapy was found effective in reducing pain and improving stiffness and quality of life, though the evidence was limited by methodological flaws, heterogeneity, and lack of double-blind design.
population_specificity: Patients with osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update the current understanding of the liver toxicity potential of Bakuchi (Psoralea corylifolia) as part of traditional Indian medicine.
results_summary: The study highlights that Bakuchi has inherent hepatotoxicity, with reported liver injuries that can be self-limiting but may progress to acute liver failure or acute chronic liver failure with high mortality.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on traditional medicine users).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify patient characteristics associated with clinical response to Comano thermal spring water balneotherapy in pediatric atopic dermatitis (AD) patients.
results_summary: Balneotherapy significantly improved AD severity, particularly in children ≤4 years old, those with early-onset AD, severe AD, or coexistent food allergies. The treatment was well-tolerated with no relevant adverse effects reported.
population_specificity: 867 children aged ≤16 years (50.5% female, mean age 5.9 years) with mild to severe AD.
study_duration: April to October 2014 (exact duration per patient not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of balneotherapy on oxidative stress, pain, depression, and quality of life in patients with fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS) compared to healthy controls.
results_summary: Balneotherapy significantly reduced oxidative stress (TOS and OSI levels) and improved clinical parameters (pain, depression, and quality of life) in FMS patients, though TAS levels remained unchanged.
population_specificity: 35 female FMS patients (mean age 39.9±5.8 years) and 35 healthy female controls (mean age 37.9±6.6 years).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated, but involved 15 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding balneotherapy to standard physical therapy improves outcomes in patients with subacute supraspinatus tendinopathy.
results_summary: The study found that adding balneotherapy to physical therapy significantly improved shoulder ROM, pain, handgrip strength, functional status, and quality of life compared to physical therapy alone, with statistically significant differences in most measured parameters.
population_specificity: 90 patients with subacute supraspinatus tendinopathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of combining balneotherapy with group psychoeducation (BT-PE) compared to balneotherapy alone (BT) in reducing burden, depression, anxiety, maladjustment, and improving care satisfaction among informal caregivers of elderly dependents.
results_summary: The BT-PE program resulted in reduced burden and increased care satisfaction for both primary and secondary caregivers, with primary caregivers also showing lower maladjustment. While depressive symptoms and anxiety decreased in both groups, BT-PE did not outperform BT alone in these outcomes.
population_specificity: Informal caregivers (primary and secondary) of elderly dependents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of balneotherapy combined with physical therapy versus physical therapy alone on pain, quality of life, and disability in individuals with chronic low back pain, and to examine the influence of BMI on treatment outcomes.
results_summary: Balneotherapy combined with physical therapy was more effective than physical therapy alone, showing statistically significant improvements in pain, quality of life, fatigue, and disability. BMI influenced outcomes, with higher BMI categories showing greater improvements in most variables except quality of life.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic low back pain, categorized by BMI (18.5-24.9 kg/m², 25.0-29.9 kg/m², ≥30.0 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 20 minutes per session in thermo-mineralized water pool (38-40°C), 5 days per week for 3 weeks (total 15 sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the analgesic effect of balneotherapy using water from Santo Amaro da Imperatriz springs in a murine model of neuropathic pain.
results_summary: Balneotherapy reduced mechanical hyperalgesia, decreased BDNF and NOS2 levels in the spinal cord, and increased BDNF and NOS1 levels in the paw, demonstrating analgesic effects in neuropathic pain. The study suggests potential benefits but calls for future clinical trials in human patients.
population_specificity: Murine (mouse) model of neuropathic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize systematic reviews with meta-analysis of balneotherapy and spa therapy based on randomized controlled trials and provide a perspective for future research.
results_summary: Balneotherapy and spa therapy provided significant pain relief and improved quality of life in chronic musculoskeletal and connective tissue diseases, and underwater exercise enhanced physical fitness and function across diseases.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic diseases of the musculoskeletal system, connective tissues, circulatory system, nervous system, and unspecified symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the benefits of a 3-week outpatient balneotherapy program on patient-reported outcomes, including symptom intensity and health-related quality of life (HRQL).
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in HRQL, reduced fatigue, and decreased anxiety/depression, but also noted an increase in fear of falling. Perceived functional status remained stable except for anxiety/depression.
population_specificity: Elderly participants aged over 65 (average age 72.5 years, 67% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to retrospectively evaluate the symptomatic effects of mud-bath therapy in patients with hand osteoarthritis (HOA) as a complementary treatment.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pain, functionality, and other assessed parameters, except for the physical component score of SF-12. Both patients and physicians reported high satisfaction with the treatment's efficacy and tolerability.
population_specificity: 212 outpatients with primary bilateral hand osteoarthritis (HOA).
effective_dosage: 12 daily local mud packs and generalized thermal baths with sulfurous-arsenical-ferruginous mineral water.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of balneotherapy on BMI, adipokine levels, sleep disturbances, and quality of life in women with morbid obesity.
results_summary: Balneotherapy significantly improved sleep quality and quality of life, reduced blood glucose, leptin, and visfatin levels, and increased adiponectin levels, but did not significantly alter BMI, WHR, or adipose tissue percentage.
population_specificity: Fifty-four women with morbid obesity.
effective_dosage: 15 sessions of balneotherapy for 20 minutes each.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied to be the duration of 15 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of Jeju magma-seawater (JMS) bathing on knee osteoarthritis (OA) and its potential synergistic effects with diclofenac sodium.
results_summary: JMS bathing reduced joint thickness, improved mobility, preserved tissue integrity, increased bone mineral density, and lowered Mankin scores in cartilage. It showed anti-inflammatory, chondroprotective, anti-apoptotic, and chondrogenic effects, with potential synergy when combined with diclofenac sodium.
population_specificity: Rats with induced knee OA via anterior cruciate ligament transection and partial meniscectomy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (bathing duration and frequency implied but not detailed).
interactions: Combination with diclofenac sodium suggested synergistic effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if supplementary balneotherapy with Chinese herbal medicine (CHM) could enhance treatment outcomes and prolong remission in patients with psoriasis vulgaris.
results_summary: The study found that combined CHM balneotherapy and narrowband ultraviolet B significantly prolonged remission time (10.99 months vs. 7.94 months) and reduced recurrence risk compared to unconsolidated therapy, with no reported adverse reactions.
population_specificity: 200 patients with moderate-to-severe plaque psoriasis.
study_duration: Treatment period from January 2013 to June 2014 (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the health benefits, clinical relevance, and persistence of effects of a 3-week balneotherapy intervention in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that 45 out of 60 patients in the experimental group experienced pain relief and other benefits, with clinically relevant improvements that persisted for 3 months post-treatment compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 120 patients with knee osteoarthritis, randomly assigned to experimental or control groups.
effective_dosage: Daily whirlpool baths, hydrokinesitherapy sessions, and knee shower/massages for 3 weeks.
study_duration: 3 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of balneotherapy using sulfurous water on pain, joint mobility, cartilage deterioration, and oxidative damage in an experimental model of osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Balneotherapy in sulfur-rich water reduced pain levels, improved joint mobility, decreased cartilage deterioration, and lowered oxidative damage markers compared to tap water and non-treated controls, though it did not affect synovial inflammation.
population_specificity: Wistar rats with experimentally induced osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of balneotherapy (BT) on pain, disability, and quality of life in patients with chronic shoulder pain compared to physical therapy alone.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in pain, disability, and quality of life for both groups, with the BT group showing greater improvements than the physical therapy-only group at both postintervention timepoints. The BT group demonstrated superior outcomes on multiple subscales of the Nottingham Health Profile, particularly for pain, energy levels, physical activity, and sleep.
population_specificity: 60 patients with chronic shoulder pain admitted to an outpatient clinic in Turkey between April 2016 and September 2016.

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of balneotherapy in modifying risk factors and lifestyle for cardiovascular disease prevention under resort and non-resort conditions.
results_summary: The study found improvements in endpoints like blood pressure, body mass index, lipid profile, physical activity, and morbidity/mortality rates, but results were limited by high heterogeneity in trial protocols and methodological quality.
population_specificity: Individuals with or at risk of cardiovascular disease (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of mineral water with varying mineral content on musculoskeletal pain and related symptoms.
results_summary: Mineral water baths had a small effect on pain and a medium effect on other symptoms like sleep quality and flexibility, with benefits lasting up to 3 months. Tap water showed short-term pain relief, while mineral water was more beneficial than tap water or no treatment.
population_specificity: 145 participants with musculoskeletal pain.
effective_dosage: 20 g/L, 40 g/L, and 60 g/L mineral water baths.
study_duration: 2 weeks of treatment with a 3-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of balneotherapy (mineral water baths and mud applications) combined with physical therapy on the functional state and pain levels of patients with knee joint osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy significantly improved walking speed, knee joint function, and pain reduction compared to physical therapy alone, with sustained benefits observed one month post-treatment. Positive changes in physical activity and pain reduction were noted in the intervention groups, though no significant differences were found in KOOS subscale averages.
population_specificity: 92 adults with grade I-III knee joint OA (Kellgren and Lawrence scoring system).
effective_dosage: 10 mineral water bath or mud application procedures plus physical therapy, administered every other day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term effectiveness of balneotherapy for patients with chronic pelvic pain (CPP).
results_summary: The study found improvements in pain, bladder irritation symptoms, and quality of life, along with significant reductions in inflammatory markers IL-1 and TNF-α after balneotherapy. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: 16 patients with chronic pelvic pain.
effective_dosage: 10 heated seawater baths (38°C, 20 minutes) and 10 mud-pack applications (40°C, 10 minutes) over five days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining balneotherapy with physical therapy was more effective than physical therapy alone for improving outcomes in elderly patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy combined with physical therapy significantly improved pain, stiffness, physical function, quality of life, fatigue, and sleepiness compared to physical therapy alone, with a higher responder rate (98.74% vs. 89.04%).
population_specificity: Patients aged 65 years and older with knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of balneotherapy for treating chronic venous insufficiency (CVI).
results_summary: Balneotherapy showed moderate improvements in pain, quality of life, and skin pigmentation but had no clear effect on disease severity, leg ulcers, or edema. Adverse events were minimal, with no serious complications reported.
population_specificity: Outpatients in secondary care with chronic venous insufficiency (891 participants across seven studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the therapeutic use of sulfurous mineral baths in Solec-Zdroj, Poland, focusing on mechanisms, benefits, and risks of sulfide treatment for chronic skin disorders and other diseases.
results_summary: The study highlights the benefits of sulfurous balneotherapy for chronic skin disorders and other diseases but notes potential risks, particularly for the skin. It emphasizes that healing effects do not correlate with sulfur content and stresses the importance of staying within safe hormetic boundaries.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic skin disorders and other diseases, though not explicitly specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of balneotherapy (Mg-Ca-SO4 thermal water baths) combined with mountain hiking on pain, orthopedic parameters, and psychophysiological outcomes in patients with non-specific chronic low back pain.
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy combined with mountain hiking (GEBT group) significantly improved pain, orthopedic parameters, health-related quality of life, and mental well-being compared to mountain hiking alone (GE group) or no intervention (CO group). The benefits were observed over a 120-day follow-up period.
population_specificity: Eighty patients with diagnosed non-specific chronic low back pain (nscLBP).
effective_dosage: Daily baths in Mg-Ca-SO4 thermal water (specific volume and duration not detailed in the abstract).
study_duration: 6 days of intervention with a 120-day follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of balneotherapy in improving cognitive function and neurotrophic factor levels in patients with chronic cerebral ischemia.
results_summary: Balneotherapy increased BDNF levels and improved cognitive and emotional outcomes in patients, with significant improvements noted in both treatment groups compared to the untreated control group.
population_specificity: 72 patients (9 men, 63 women, mean age 62.2±2.1 years) with 1st or 2nd stage chronic cerebral ischemia.
effective_dosage: Group 1: hydrogen sulphide muds and baths (number 7), daily neck-collar massage, and exercise therapy. Group 2: standard course of chloride-sodium bromine baths (number 7).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-frequency balneotherapy versus low-frequency balneotherapy combined with land-based exercise on improving postural control in knee osteoarthritis patients.
results_summary: High-frequency balneotherapy improved postural control at 3 weeks, with sustained effects over 12 weeks, while low-frequency balneotherapy required additional land-based exercise to show improvement, which did not persist over time.
population_specificity: 236 knee osteoarthritis patients (mean age 64 years).
effective_dosage: 3 weeks of continuous (high-frequency) or discontinuous (low-frequency) balneotherapy sessions, with the same total number of sessions for both groups.
study_duration: 3 weeks for Gr1, 6 weeks for Gr2 (3 weeks balneotherapy + 3 weeks land-based exercise).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of mineral water "Naftusia" on the immunological status of women with non-calcular cholecystitis and thyroid hyperplasia, and to assess its potential for balneotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that mineral water "Naftusia" positively influenced the immune system, normalizing cellular and phagocytic immunity, likely through improved cell division and differentiation at the membrane level.
population_specificity: Women with non-calcular cholecystitis and thyroid hyperplasia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of regulatory T cells in the anti-inflammatory effects of balneotherapy and assess its impact on neutrophil-mediated innate responses in elderly osteoarthritis patients.
results_summary: Balneotherapy significantly improved clinical outcomes, reduced IL-8 and TGF-β levels, altered regulatory T cell percentages, and enhanced neutrophil function, correlating with reduced pain and improved joint mobility.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Daily whole-body mud therapy at 40-42°C for 10 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the combined effects of moderate mountain hiking and balneotherapy on gait, balance, body composition, and quality of life in high-functioning older adults aged 65-85 years.
results_summary: The study found short-term improvements in static balance and gait speed, as well as sustained improvements in quality of life and body composition (e.g., total body water, appendicular muscle mass) in the intervention group receiving balneotherapy and hiking. No significant changes were observed in dynamic balance or self-assessed balance confidence.
population_specificity: High-functioning older adults aged 65-85 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (balneotherapy was applied during a seven-day holiday).
study_duration: Seven days (with follow-ups at day 7, day 60, and day 180).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the utilization and social insurance indicators of publicly funded spa therapy in Hungary between 2009 and 2016.
results_summary: The study found a gradual decrease in spa treatment counts over the years, with "spa pool of medicinal water" being the most common treatment. Territorial disparities in utilization were observed, with higher usage in Csongrád county and among individuals aged 60-69.
population_specificity: Patients receiving publicly funded spa therapy in Hungary, with data stratified by age, sex, and county.
study_duration: Data covered 2009-2016, but individual treatment durations are not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the clinical effects of balneotherapy in patients with chronic inflammatory rheumatic diseases by reviewing randomized controlled trials (RCTs).
results_summary: Balneotherapy showed beneficial effects, particularly in patients with axial involvement (e.g., ankylosing spondylitis), but less favorable outcomes in those with peripheral articular inflammation (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis). It appeared safe, with few reported adverse events.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic inflammatory rheumatic diseases, including ankylosing spondylitis, enteropathic spondylitis, rheumatoid arthritis, and psoriatic arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms, applications, and potential benefits of balneotherapy for various medical conditions, including musculoskeletal, dermatological, and neurological diseases.
results_summary: Balneotherapy was found to be effective for relieving muscle tension, improving various diseases, and aiding rehabilitation, though further research is needed to confirm its effectiveness, safety, and standard procedures.
population_specificity: Patients with musculoskeletal diseases, dermatological diseases, immuno-inflammatory diseases, chronic pain syndromes, chronic cardiac diseases, metabolic syndromes, neurological diseases, and psychiatric conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory and analgesic effects of Hévíz thermal water and mud in murine models of osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis.
results_summary: Hévíz medicinal water and combined treatment with water and mud significantly reduced mechanical hyperalgesia and knee edema in the osteoarthritis model but had no effect on hyperalgesia, weight bearing, or edema in the rheumatoid arthritis model. Neither treatment ameliorated deep structural joint or bone damage in either model.
population_specificity: Female NMRI mice (n=6-8 per group) with induced osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis.
study_duration: Duration not explicitly stated, but treatments were administered every working day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of balneotherapy, mud-pack therapy, mud-bath therapy, and spa therapy in treating knee osteoarthritis by analyzing pain reduction, functional improvement, drug use, and quality of life.
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy and related therapies were effective in reducing pain, decreasing nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug consumption, improving functional limitations, and enhancing quality of life in knee osteoarthritis patients. However, methodological differences among studies prevented a meta-analysis.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether balneotherapy and spa therapy significantly improve Quality of Life (QoL) in patients with knee osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy and spa therapy significantly improved QoL in patients with knee OA, with long-term benefits in overall QoL and pain reduction. No significant difference was observed in social function compared to sham interventions.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on balneotherapy's effects on skin diseases and describe its use in three different treatment sites with unique climates and mineral water properties.
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy, particularly when combined with phototherapy (balneophototherapy), enhances anti-inflammatory effects and benefits dermatologic conditions like psoriasis and atopic dermatitis. The therapeutic effects were observed across three distinct thermal spring sites with varying climates and water compositions.
population_specificity: Patients with dermatologic and rheumatologic diseases, particularly psoriasis and atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the biological mechanisms and effectiveness of balneotherapy in treating low-grade inflammation- and stress-related pathologies, focusing on neuroendocrine and immunological responses.
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy induces anti-inflammatory, analgesic, antioxidant, chondroprotective, and anabolic effects through neuroendocrine-immune regulation, with hormesis playing a critical role in these mechanisms. The beneficial effects align with the concept of hormesis, supported by factors like heat and specific biochemical components (e.g., hydrogen sulfide and radon).
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on low-grade inflammation- and stress-related pathologies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether balneotherapy, mud/peloid therapy, and spa therapy influence cortisol levels and improve stress resilience.
results_summary: Balneotherapy showed potential to influence cortisol levels in healthy subjects, improving stress resilience, while spa therapy demonstrated similar effects in sub-healthy subjects and patients with diagnosed diseases. No significant variations were found in patients with rheumatic conditions, and no studies assessed mud/peloid therapy alone.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects, sub-healthy subjects, and patients with diagnosed diseases (e.g., rheumatic conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and tolerability of balneotherapy (BT) using highly mineralized sulfate water in patients with primary fibromyalgia syndrome (FS).
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pain (VAS) and fibromyalgia impact (FIQ-Total) in the BT group, persisting for 6 months, with no significant improvements in the control group. Adverse events were fewer in the BT group (10 patients) compared to the control group (22 patients).
population_specificity: Patients with primary fibromyalgia syndrome (100 participants).
effective_dosage: Not specified (cycle of BT with highly mineralized sulfate water).
study_duration: 2 weeks of treatment, with follow-up at 3 and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of a 3-week balneotherapy-based rehabilitation protocol in improving psoriasis symptoms and reducing inflammation.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in both PASI scores (7.15 to 2.62) and CRP levels (4.1 to 3.5) after the 3-week intervention, indicating improved psoriasis symptoms and reduced inflammation. A negative correlation was observed between PASI improvement and the number of spa therapies received.
population_specificity: Eighty psoriatic patients undergoing inward balneotherapy-based rehabilitation.
effective_dosage: Not specified (spa therapy frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of a 21-day balneotherapy program on blood parameters in servicemen with sub-health conditions.
results_summary: Balneotherapy significantly improved MCH, MCHC, and WBC levels while reducing LAC, ALT, GLU, and TG levels. No significant changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: 129 servicemen in sub-health conditions.
effective_dosage: Whole-body immersion in thermomineral water for 30 minutes daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of balneotherapy on relieving pain and stiffness and improving physical function in patients with knee osteoarthritis compared to controls.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that balneotherapy was clinically effective in relieving pain and stiffness and improving function, as measured by WOMAC scores, though high heterogeneity (88-93%) was observed among studies. The quality of current publications contributed to this heterogeneity.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of mud-bath therapy (MBT) on microRNA expression levels and clinical parameters in patients with bilateral knee osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: MBT significantly improved clinical parameters (pain and WOMAC scores) and reduced expression levels of miR-155, miR-181a, miR-146a, and miR-223 in OA patients, while no changes were observed in the control group. No significant variations were found for miR-let-7e in either group.
population_specificity: Thirty-two patients with bilateral knee osteoarthritis (OA) defined by ACR criteria.
effective_dosage: Daily local mud-packs at 42°C and baths in mineral water at 37°C for 15 minutes, 12 applications over 2 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if balneotherapy modifies circulating levels of S1P and inflammatory markers in OA patients and assess their relationship to therapeutic efficacy.
results_summary: Balneotherapy significantly reduced S1P levels and pain/stiffness while improving physical function, with positive correlations between S1P and inflammatory markers like HSP-70, COX-2, and MMP-3.
population_specificity: 40 OA patients with generalized osteoarthritis in at least 3 body positions, meeting ACR and Kellgren-Moore criteria.
effective_dosage: 20-minute full-body immersion in thermo-mineral water (38°C–40°C), 15 sessions over 15 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if spa therapy (balneotherapy) combined with pharmacological treatment provides additional benefits for rheumatoid arthritis (RA) management compared to pharmacological treatment alone.
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy improved HAQ-DI scores (a measure of functional ability) at 21 days and 3 months post-treatment, with statistically significant results (P = 0.01 and P = 0.004, respectively). The authors concluded that balneotherapy enhances quality of life, particularly for patients where pain predominates.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) meeting American College of Rheumatology criteria.
effective_dosage: 21 days of spa treatments at S. Jorge Spa-Santa Maria da Feira (specific frequency not detailed).
study_duration: 21 days of intervention, with follow-up at 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of hot spring balneotherapy on mental stress, sleep disorders, general health problems, and women's health issues in sub-healthy individuals.
results_summary: Balneotherapy significantly improved sleep disorders, mental stress, and general health problems (e.g., head pain, joint pain) compared to the control group. Some women's health issues and other indicators (e.g., fatigue, constipation) improved within the intervention group but showed no significant difference between groups.
population_specificity: 362 sub-healthy volunteers (223 intervention, 139 control) in Chongqing.
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequency and length varied, influencing outcomes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of hydrokinesitherapy in a thermal setting on pain relief, joint function, and walking speed in obese patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in pain (VAS) and improvements in joint function (WOMAC, ROM) immediately after treatment and at 6-month follow-up, along with increased walking speed. However, gait analysis showed limited significant changes except for average speed and ground reaction force.
population_specificity: Obese patients (BMI 30-45 kg/m²) with knee osteoarthritis (Kellgren-Lawrence grade II-III), predominantly female (8 females, 2 males), mean age 59.4 years.
effective_dosage: Two sessions per week for 8 consecutive weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and impact of a program combining cognitive behavioral therapy, psychoeducation, and balneotherapy to facilitate long-term benzodiazepine discontinuation.
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy combined with a psychoeducational program significantly reduced benzodiazepine use by 75.3% at 6 months, with 41.4% of patients completely stopping use. Patients who discontinued benzodiazepines also showed greater improvements in anxiety and depression symptoms compared to those who only reduced use.
population_specificity: Patients with long-term benzodiazepine use seeking anxiolytic withdrawal.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of balneotherapy on serum cortisol and DHEA-S levels in fibromyalgia patients compared to controls.
results_summary: The study found lower cortisol and DHEA-S levels in fibromyalgia patients compared to controls, but balneotherapy combined with physical therapy did not significantly alter these hormone levels post-treatment.
population_specificity: 72 fibromyalgia patients and 39 healthy volunteers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of balneotherapy on fibromyalgia syndrome treatment compared to education alone.
results_summary: Balneotherapy showed statistically significant improvements in all parameters, with the most notable results observed in the first 3-month follow-up. Long-term benefits (6 months) were seen in all parameters except tender point count and modified fatigue impact.
population_specificity: 66 female patients diagnosed with fibromyalgia syndrome.
effective_dosage: 21 sessions of spa treatment with 34.8 °C thermomineral water, 5 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether saline balneotherapy influences oxidant/antioxidant status and clinical outcomes in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients.
results_summary: Balneotherapy significantly increased nonenzymatic superoxide radical scavenger activity (NSSA) and improved clinical parameters like patient/physician global assessments, function, disease activity, and swollen joint count, though pain scores showed only a trend toward improvement.
population_specificity: 50 patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
effective_dosage: 12 balneotherapy sessions (20 min daily, except Sunday) in thermal mineral water at 36-37°C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of balneotherapy on gastrointestinal motility, specifically its impact on constipation and defecation disorders in patients with osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that a 15-day course of balneotherapy significantly improved constipation scores, SF-12 health survey results, and colonic transit time, while also reducing laxative consumption in middle-aged and elderly patients.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and elderly patients with osteoarthritis and constipation/defecation disorders.
effective_dosage: Not specified (mineral water from a thermal spring in Bursa, Turkey).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the properties of thermal waters used in the Orthopaedic Rehabilitation Centre of Madagascar and explore their potential applications in post-operative rehabilitation and chronic degenerative illnesses.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on the effects of Balneotherapy, only stating the study's aim to analyze the properties and applications of the thermal waters.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing post-operative rehabilitation and those with chronic degenerative illnesses in Antsirabe, Madagascar.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the latest developments in endoscopic management of complications arising from bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that endoscopy is effective for early diagnosis and treatment of bariatric surgery complications, with innovations like stricturotomy improving outcomes for chronic leaks/fistulas. Endoscopic approaches are preferred over surgical reintervention when urgent surgery is not required.
population_specificity: Patients with complications following bariatric surgery.
